subject: RE: [junit] TDD -> FSM and Chess
msgSnippet: I just had a thought last night that I found fascinating and I think relates to this idea of TDD and FSM. The code resulting from doing TDD and that resulting
messageBody:
I just had a thought last night that I found fascinating and I think relates to this idea of TDD and FSM.

The code resulting from doing TDD and that resulting from not doing TDD might be similar to the difference between the configuration of chess pieces on a board during a real game versus that of a completely random configuration that is impossible to get to in a real game.

I read once that a chess expert will be relatively confused if presented with a chess configuration that is impossible to get to in a real game because it doesn't match the patterns they are familiar with.

Similarly, by doing TDD, it might be able to be shown that the code follows a certain pattern along the entire process. Whereas non-TDD code would not follow that and could be random.

Just thought this was a very interesting line of thought...

Joel Shellman

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Scott Stirling
> Sent: Thursday, February 06, 2003 8:18 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [junit] TDD -> FSM
>
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbr@...]
> >
> > Scott:
> >
> > Have you identified how a test-driven class implements a FSM? If I
> > give you some code that I test-drove, would you try
> identifying how it
> > is a FSM? That would be very interesting.
>
> I'd be willing to try. I would be interested to have an
> example that's not my own or borrowed out of a book. But I'm
> working with a few book examples right now, trying to sort
> things out and see how far I can take this FSM idea.
>
> Scott S.
>
